awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multiscale Proximity Algorithms for Optimization Problems Arising from Image/Signal Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Restoring images or signals from limited available data is required in variety of applications, including parallel magnetic resonance imaging in medical applications and fingerprint and face recognition in security identification. Such image or signal reconstruction problems are often modeled as large-scale optimization problems.  This research project aims to develop more efficient computational algorithms for solving these optimization problems. Results of this project are anticipated to have an impact in practical applications. In particular, the numerical schemes under development are expected to support medical imaging research and assist in improving the accuracy of clinical decisions. Senior undergraduate and graduate students are trained in the course of this project. 

This research project aims to develop multiscale proximity algorithms for optimization problems arising in image or signal processing. Signal processing problems of practical importance, such as incomplete data recovery, compressive sensing, and matrix completion, are modeled as optimization problems that have non-differentiable objective functions. A signal of interest naturally has a hierarchical structure or allows itself to be sparsely represented in a multiscale analysis. Multiscale analysis, as a convenient tool for computation, however, is mainly used to sparsify the underlying signal in formulating optimization problems; it is not fully exploited in development of efficient algorithms for optimization problems. In this project, to make systematic use of the hierarchical structure that exists in optimization problems of interest, the investigators will synthesize and combine multiscale analysis and proximity algorithms to solve the problems in an accurate and computationally efficient way.

por.por_cntn:
Under the support of this grant, the PI has completed seventeen research papers, among which thirteen papers appeared/got accepted in either refereed journals or conference proceedings, and four have been submitted or under revision. The work in all these papers is either directly related to the core research of the grant or concerned with the mathematical foundation for the proposed research. The results of the project inspired some of the proposed work in this current proposal.  In addition to seven joint papers with the PI mentioned above, the consultant Dr. Xu published four more papers with this grant acknowledged in publications.

Joined SUNY Upstate Medical University, a US patent 9460494 for a project that enhances medical imaging research was issued by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in 2016. This patent that is titled  ``Methods and systems for inverse problem reconstruction and application to ECT reconstruction'' was supported by the current NSF award and the prior NSF award DMS-1115523. This work has been developed into a collaborative project to enhance the quality of PET reconstruction with Memorial Sloan Kattering Cancer Center and SUNY Upstate Medical University. 

The research supported by this NSF award has significant impact to education and human resources. The PI offered at Syracuse University (SU) a two semester-long course on optimization in 2016, in which he integrated the topics and results of this research project. As a result of this course, three students of SU each year of 2016, 2017, and 2018 were offered summer internships at the Air Force Research Laboratory.Ph.D. student Feishe Chen of the PI completed his Ph.D program in 2015, having six publications with the PI. He is now employed by Ebay. Ph.D. student Ms. Xiaoxia Liu, of the PI and Dr. Xu, graduated in June of 2018, will be a post-doc in Shenzhen University, China. The PI has successfully recruited three Ph.D students,  Mr. Stephen Farnham, Mr. Xuefei Ma, and Ms. Erin Tripp. Mr. Farnham passed his qualifying exams in the summer of 2017 and plans to write his dissertation on nonlinear phase unwinding of functions. Mr. Ma passed his qualifying exams in January of 2017 and plans to write his dissertation on nonlinear optimization and machine learning. Ms. Tripp passed her qualifying exams in the summer of 2017. In summer of 2018, Ms Tripp joint with the PI submitted a research paper to an international journal. 

Finally, the PI organized a special session at 2018 SIAM conference on imaging science (IS18).
